Description: Fragment of lower body and flaring conical foot of South Ionian pottery cup, probably with everted rim; interior reserved with two black circles; exterior glazed; underside reserved; accidental black drips on bowl; inscription on underside.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2
Curator's comments: The lack of a rim prevents a definitive identification of the cup as a South Ionian cup with everted rim. However, the fabric and pattern find parallels with Hayes' Ionian Cup Type VIII (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116). Hayes' Type VIII is of the same shape as his Type IX (only the interior decoration is different) which coincides with Schlotzhauer's (Schlotzhauer 2012) Type 9A. The type closely follows the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18), Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116), and Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
The fabric sems to be East Greek rather than Attic, though the shape and syntax are close to Atic pieces such as Sparkes 1970a, no. 378, pl. 18.
Bibliographic references: Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p.259, no.8)
Johnston 2006a / Trademarks on Greek Vases: Addenda (East Greek 213)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.468) (Phase 3)
